did.head: Descriptive Summary

langmaterial.language: The language of the materials is English

did.abstract: The papers of an Assistant Professor and Professor at Willimantic State College/Eastern Connecticut State College

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The Burstermann Collection was received by the Archives during the 2001 Academic Year. The material was donated by former ECSU Alumna/Faculty/Administrator, Margaret S. Wilson. Additional information was provided by several other departments on the ECSU campus.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Juliette Virginia Phifer was born in Charlotte, North Carolina on January 3, 1905. Following her graduation in 1928 from Slater State Normal School in Winston-Salem, NC, Juliette pursued an education in Elementary Education at the Winston-Salem Teachers College. She received a Bachelor of Science degree from that institution in 1929. During those years (the time line is not clear) Ms. Phifer taught elementary school for seven years--teaching in each of the seven grades within the school. She received her Master of Arts in Education in 1933 from the Teachers College of Columbia University in NY. From 1933 to 1934, Juliette taught at the Newbold Training School, which was associated with the State Teachers College in Fayetteville, NC. In 1934-1935, she was on leave from the Fayetteville Teachers College and was the State Supervisor of Adult Education at the North Carolina, USA Federal Emergency Relief Program. The following year, she returned to the Newbold Training School as the principal and remained there until 1946. Meanwhile in 1942, Ms. Burstermann embarked on her quest to obtain a doctoral degree in education, and commenced her studies at New York University. She completed all of the requirements and obtained the degree in 1948. That same year she was hired as an Assistant Professor at Willimantic State Teachers College, and held that designation until 1958. In 1959 she was promoted to the rank of full professor and remained at ECSC until her retirement in 1974. Juliette, the first African-American faculty member at this institution, was married in New York to Louis C. Burstermann in 1952 or 1953.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Burstermann Collection is a history of Juliette P. Burstermann's life at Eastern Connecticut State University, commencing in August of 1948 and continuing through her retirement 1974. The collection includes materials relating to her involvement with numerous outside organizations and committees during that same period as well as information related to her post-retirement activities from 1975-1992.

The items in this category relate to both Dr. Burstermann's personal and professional involvement in various organizations, as well as awards she received including Delta Gamma Kappa Society, AAUW, Connecticut Division, Association for Arts in Childhood and Quality of Life Executive Committee .

The material in this series generally relates to Dr. Burstermann's professional involvement in various organizations including "Modern Math", Head Start Training and WCCI World Conference on Education.
The correspondence in this series is both personal and professional, relating to various apsects of Dr. Burstermann's activities while at Eastern.
This part of the collection contains syllabi and course descriptions as prepared by Dr. Burstermann.
This series contains personal information about her life including transcripts, hiring confirmation, promotion material as well as biographical information.
The items in this series include various types of printed material which were written by Dr. Burstermann or saved among her papers.
The photographs in this collection are a pictorial history of Dr. Burstermann's life as an educator dating from the 1940s to the 1980s.

This series includes a 1972 portrait-style photograph of Dr. Bursterman; two copies of Education for Peace a book in which she wrote Part I of Chapter 4 (one signed; one personalized to Margaret and William Wilson); a video-taped interview with Dr. Burstermann dated April 1989 and 4 ribboned name tags from various conventions.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files are grouped into 8 series:

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The University Archives has a substantial collection of University Archives material and also houses the Connecticut Studies Collection. For more detailed information on these collections please contact the staff member at the reference desk.
